text: So if you can focus the messaging in a way that speaks to something that has a bit of shock value or is counterintuitive, you'll get them to continue reading. So first and foremost is relevancy.
speaker: Jen Abel
context: Lenny asks Jen how founders can get prospects to pay attention when so many SaaS tools are constantly emailing potential customers. Jen explains that founders need to cut through the noise by crafting messages that stand out. She emphasizes that relevancy is more important than personalization, and founders should lead with something that has shock value or is counterintuitive to make prospects pause and want to learn more.
text_ko: 따라서 메시지(messaging)를 충격 요소(shock value)가 있거나 직관에 반하는(counterintuitive) 방향으로 맞춰 전달하면 사람들이 계속 읽게 만들 수 있어요. 그래서 무엇보다도 가장 중요한 건 관련성(relevancy)이에요.
text_zh: 所以如果你能把信息包装得有点震撼性或者反常理的感觉，就能抓住他们继续看下去。说到底，最重要的还是相关性。
text_es: Entonces, si puedes enfocar el mensaje de una manera que hable de algo que tenga cierto impacto o que vaya contra lo que esperan, vas a lograr que sigan leyendo. Así que lo más importante es la relevancia.

text: You need to be vulnerable. I would be very open and honest with where you are. Hey, I'm an early stage startup. We have a lot to learn. Can we kind of gain your insight into how this problem is manifesting on your side? Founder led sales is not about revenue on day one. It is about learning as fast as humanly possible to get to that pulse, so that you can earn the right to sell.
speaker: Jen Abel
context: Lenny asks what founders should do once they're on a phone call with a prospect to get them to engage further. Jen explains that founders should be vulnerable about being early-stage rather than pretending to have a fully-built product. This honesty gets better feedback because prospects are more willing to give candid input when they know they can influence the product before it's finalized. The goal at this stage is learning, not immediate revenue.
text_ko: 너무 솔직해지는 게 중요해요. 지금 내가 어떤 상황인지에 대해 개방적이고 정직하게 이야기하는 게 좋겠어요. 저희는 초기 스타트업이고, 배울 게 정말 많아요. 이 문제를 당신 쪽에서 어떻게 겪고 있는지에 대한 통찰을 얻을 수 있을까요? 창업자가 이끄는 세일즈는 첫날부터 수익을 내는 게 아니에요. 가능한 한 빨리 배우는 게 중요하고, 그 과정을 통해 고객의 니즈를 파악해야 나중에 판매할 수 있는 자격을 얻는 거예요.
text_zh: 你得放下身段，坦诚一点。我会很开放很真诚地说出现在的情况。就直接说，嘿，我们是个早期创业公司，还有很多要学的。能不能跟我们分享一下，这个问题在你们那边是怎么表现的？创始人亲自做销售，第一天不是为了收入，而是要尽快学习，摸到市场的脉搏，这样才能赢得销售的资格。
text_es: Tienes que ser vulnerable. Yo sería súper abierto y honesto sobre dónde estás parado. Oye, somos una startup en etapa temprana. Tenemos mucho que aprender. ¿Podríamos conocer tu perspectiva sobre cómo se está manifestando este problema de tu lado? Las ventas lideradas por el fundador (founder led sales) no se tratan de generar ingresos desde el primer día. Se trata de aprender lo más rápido humanamente posible para captar esa esencia, para que puedas ganarte el derecho a vender.

text: When they start getting their gears churning in their head about, and this is the beauty about not having a product and not showing them anything, they're visualizing in their head now. This is a really powerful thing, which is like, so tell me how this looks in your head?
speaker: Jen Abel
context: Jen is explaining how to identify if there's real interest during sales conversations. She advises founders to avoid showing demos too early and instead get prospects talking about the problem. When prospects start visualizing solutions in their minds without seeing a product, it's a powerful signal of genuine interest. Founders should ask prospects to describe what they're imagining to gather valuable insights.
text_ko: 사람들이 머릿속에서 생각이 막 굴러가기 시작할 때요. 제품이 없고 아무것도 보여주지 않는 것의 묘미가 바로 그거예요 — 지금 스스로 머릿속으로 상상하고 있다는 거죠. 이건 정말 강력한 일이에요. 그러니까, 머릿속에는 어떻게 보이나요?
text_zh: 当他们开始在脑子里转悠这些想法的时候，这就是不展示产品、什么都不给他们看的妙处——他们现在完全是在脑子里想象画面。这招特别厉害，你就问他们：跟我说说，你脑子里想的是什么样子？
text_es: Cuando empiezan a darle vueltas en la cabeza y aquí está lo bueno de no tener un producto y no enseñarles nada, porque ahora se están imaginando todo mentalmente. Esto es súper poderoso, entonces les preguntas: "oye, cuéntame cómo te lo imaginas tú"

text: With that, you can literally turn a customer into a guide by asking them to co-author the scope. The scope of work. The co-authorship piece is important for two reasons. It helps you understand where they're on their biomaturity.
speaker: Jen Abel
context: Jen explains how to make prospects feel invested in the solution during later sales conversations. By asking prospects to co-author the scope of work, founders can assess the prospect's buying maturity - whether they have existing processes and strategies to solve the problem. If they lack these foundations, they may need to buy services first before purchasing technology, which is common for 40-50% of B2B SaaS companies according to Jen's experience.
vocabulary_highlights: turn a customer into a guide
text_ko: 이렇게 하면 고객에게 작업 범위(scope of work)를 공동 저작(co-author)하도록 요청해서, 말 그대로 고객을 가이드로 만들 수 있어요. 공동 저작(co-authorship)은 두 가지 이유로 중요해요. 그중 하나는 그들이 바이오성숙도(biomaturity)의 어느 단계에 있는지 파악하는 데 도움이 되기 때문이에요.
text_zh: 这样一来，你就可以让客户当你的向导，让他们跟你一起来定项目范围。工作范围嘛。这个共同制定很重要，有两个原因。一个是能帮你了解他们现在处在什么发展阶段。
text_es: Con eso, literalmente puedes convertir a un cliente en tu guía pidiéndole que colabore contigo en definir el alcance del proyecto. Esa parte de trabajar juntos en el documento es clave por dos razones. Te ayuda a entender en qué punto están con su madurez biológica (biomaturity).

text: If you don't, it's so easy for it to just go there and die. Another piece that's important with procurement is explaining exactly what you do and don't do. Because if you say you do a bunch of things and they can't really place you, they're going to send you to the kitchen sink of contracting an MSA.
speaker: Jen Abel
context: Jen is explaining how to navigate the procurement process in enterprise sales. She advises founders to do most of the paperwork themselves to make the procurement team's job easier, since startups are often small deals that can get sidelined. She warns that if procurement can't easily classify what a startup does, they'll default to high-risk contracting requirements that can kill deals.
text_ko: 그걸 안 하면 그냥 거기서 묻혀 버리기 쉬워요. 조달 쪽에서 또 중요한 한 가지는 우리가 정확히 뭘 하고 뭘 안 하는지 분명히 설명하는 거예요. 여러 가지를 다 한다고 해놓고 상대가 우리를 어떤 카테고리에 넣어야 할지 모르면 결국엔 모든 걸 다 끼워넣는 식으로 마스터 서비스 계약(Master Service Agreement, MSA)으로 몰아버리려고 해요.
text_zh: 如果你不这样做的话，很容易就石沉大海了。采购这块还有个重要的点，就是要把你做什么、不做什么说得特别清楚。因为如果你说你什么都能做，他们又搞不清楚你到底是干嘛的，那就会把你扔到那种什么都管的万能合同(MSA)里去。
text_es: Si no lo haces, es súper fácil que todo se vaya al traste y muera ahí mismo. Otra cosa clave con las compras es explicar exactamente qué haces y qué no haces. Porque si dices que haces un montón de cosas y no te pueden ubicar bien, te van a mandar al cajón de sastre de contratos con un MSA.

text: It's qualification. Qualification because if you spend your time on the wrong leads, that equates to a zero. So if you don't get that first level right, let me put it this way, everyone that I know says they have a bottom of funnel problem. It's never a bottom of funnel problem. It's a top of funnel problem.
speaker: Jen Abel
context: Lenny asks Jen where founders most commonly get stuck in the sales process and where there's the biggest opportunity to improve conversion. Jen explains that the biggest issue is qualification - talking to the wrong prospects or using the wrong messaging. She notes that founders often think they have closing problems when they actually have qualification problems at the top of their sales funnel.
text_ko: 핵심은 적격성 판단(qualification)이에요. 잘못된 리드(leads)에 시간을 쓰면 결과는 제로예요. 그래서 그 첫 단계(첫 레벨)를 제대로 못 잡으면, 이렇게 말할게요: 제가 아는 사람들은 다들 '퍼널 하단(bottom of funnel) 문제'라고 하는데, 사실 그건 절대 그런 문제가 아니에요. 늘 퍼널 상단(top of funnel) 문제예요.
text_zh: 关键是要筛选客户。为什么这么说呢？如果你把时间浪费在不靠谱的潜在客户(leads)身上，那就等于白忙活。所以如果你第一步就没做对，我这么跟你说吧，我认识的人都说他们漏斗底部(bottom of funnel)有问题。其实根本不是底部的问题，而是漏斗顶部(top of funnel)出了问题。
text_es: Es puro tema de calificación. Calificación porque si te gastas el tiempo con los leads equivocados, eso se traduce en cero resultados. Entonces, si no haces bien ese primer nivel, te lo pongo así: todo el mundo que conozco dice que tiene un problema en la parte baja del embudo (bottom of funnel). Nunca es un problema de abajo del embudo. Es un problema de arriba del embudo (top of funnel).
